docs.lead_paragraph: Coma and Court Fight Recede Into the Past It was a private family tragedy that strangers turned into a national spectacle. In December 1988, Nancy Klein was a 32-year-old resident of Upper Brookville on Long Island, and was 10 weeks pregnant, when she was in an automobile accident that left her in a coma. Six weeks later, with no sign that she would emerge from it, her husband, Martin -- saying doctors had told him that ending the pregnancy would improve her chances of recovering -- asked a state court to appoint him as her guardian so he could authorize an abortion.
docs.abstract: Following Up column; Nancy Klein was 10 weeks pregnant when she was in car accident in 1988, and went into coma; her husband Martin was appointed guardian and authorized abortion, although opponents, who were strangers to family, tried to block procedure; Kleins have since divorced; Nancy Klein is still mildly brain damaged and feels strongly that people had no right to interfere with her husband's decision; New York Supreme Court Justice Barbara R Kapnick has ordered Jose A Ramos, leading suspect in 1979 disappearance of Etan Patz, to pay Etan's parents $2 million in civil suit they brough charging him with responsibility for their son's presumed abduction and death; Ramos is in prison on molestation charges and has no assets, but decision is meaningful to Patz family; photos (M)
docs.snippet: More than a decade after a private family tragedy turned into a national spectacle, those affected have moved on.

docs.lead_paragraph: These days, women aren't letting a little pregnancy get between them and their Prada. Chic mothers-in-waiting are now altering their own designer clothes to fit burgeoning bellies -- sewing elastic triangles into hip seams, adding stretch panels to waistbands or lengthening hemlines on blouses. ''When I was pregnant, I figured I may never be able to fit into my nice clothes again, so why not alter them?'' said Jeanine Lobell, the creator of Stila Cosmetics, who stitched elastic panels into the waistbands of Helmut Lang pants and the seams of Dries van Noten blouses. ''When you find a designer you like, you don't want to have to give the clothes up because you're pregnant.'' For like-minded do-it-yourselfers, the Denim Doctors at Fred Segal in Los Angeles will tailor jeans to fit an expanding girth for a fee of $30, while Liz Lange Maternity sells elasticized, pull-up versions of jeans by labels like Citizens of Humanity and Earl for $175 a pair. Bella Bands -- soft, stretchy tubes for the waist ($25.95 at www.pregnancystore.com) -- can provide wardrobe extensions by letting women wear regular skirts and pants, unbuttoned and unzipped. And Dynasty Tailors in New York City (212-679-1075) and Susie's Custom Design in Los Angeles (323-462-5520) will maternitize clothes with elastic triangles or panels for $35 to $45 a garment. DANIELLE PERGAMENT
docs.abstract: Danielle Pergament Pulse column discusses new trend in altering designer clothes to fit during pregnancy, in addition to buying maternity clothing; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: These days, women aren't letting a little pregnancy get between them and their Prada. Chic mothers-in-waiting are now altering their own designer clothes to fit burgeoning bellies - sewing elastic triangles into hip seams, adding stretch panels to...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE SECRET EPIDEMIC: The Story of AIDS and Black America, by Jacob Levenson. (Anchor, $14.) In the fall of 2000, Levenson traveled to the South, seeking answers to why African-Americans were acquiring H.I.V. at seven times the rate of whites. This unflinching history profiles a wide range of individuals transformed by the epidemic's sweep: from infected patients and their families to public health workers struggling to contain a crisis compounded by poverty, drug use and teenage pregnancy. Levenson looks at the AIDS epidemic's intersection with region, race and politics, and ''artfully threads together the ways in which this horror came to be,'' Adrian Nicole LeBlanc wrote in the Book Review. THE LAST CROSSING, by Guy Vanderhaeghe. (Grove, $14.) Vanderhaeghe's gritty, expansive novel is set in the late-19th-century wilds of northern Montana and Canada's Northwest Territories, and follows a ragged, ill-tempered crew across the Canadian border. The expedition's leaders, Charles Gaunt and his older brother, Addington, are searching for Charles's lost twin, Simon, who had arrived from England a year earlier to convert the Indians of the New World.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In a Feb. 23 letter, Wade F. Horn, an assistant secretary of health and human services, singled out the Carrera program as one that reduces adolescent pregnancies through contraception while criticizing some participants' use of Depo-Provera.
docs.abstract: Letter by Michael Carrera, director of Bernice and Milton Stern National Adolescent Sexuality Training Center, responds to Health and Human Services Asst Sec Wade F Horn Feb 23 letter; holds that rates of teenage pregnancy of Carrera program participants were markedly below national rates from 1997 to 2000, and only 22 percent used Depo-Provera to avoid unintended pregnancies

docs.lead_paragraph: A front-page article on Monday about debate over a proposed federal recommendation that all newborn babies be screened for 29 rare diseases misidentified a type of acid that can form in the blood of premature babies. It is carbonic acid (formed when carbon dioxide in the lungs combines with water in the blood), not carbolic acid.
docs.abstract: Correction of Feb 21 article on proposed federal recommendation that all newborn babies be screened for 29 rare diseases regarding premature babies

docs.lead_paragraph: A 35-year-old Long Island man was charged yesterday with killing his stepbrother's ex-wife in what one law enforcement official said was apparently an attempt to keep her from revealing that she was four months pregnant with his child. The suspect, Steven Schiovone of Levittown, ''did not want to anger his stepbrother,'' said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the investigation is continuing. ''He didn't want his stepbrother to know that he was romantically involved with her.''

headline.main: L.I. Man Charged in Death Of Stepbrother's Ex-Wife

docs.abstract: Steven Schiovone of Levittown, NY, is charged with killing Susan Ambrosino, his step-brother's ex-wife; officials say murder was attempt to keep her from revealing that she was pregnant with his child; Schiovone's lawyer contends he is innocent (M)
docs.snippet: A 35-year-old Long Island man was charged yesterday with killing his stepbrother's ex-wife in what one law enforcement official said was apparently an attempt to keep her from revealing that she was four months pregnant with his child.

docs.lead_paragraph: Attorney General Phill Kline, a Republican who has made fighting abortion a staple of his two years in the post, is demanding the complete medical files of scores of women and girls who had late-term abortions, saying on Thursday that he needs the information to prosecute criminal cases. Mr. Kline emphasized statutory rape at a news conference here but also spoke obliquely of other crimes that court documents suggest could include doctors' providing illegal late-term abortions and health professionals' failing to heed a state law that requires the reporting of suspected child sexual abuse.

headline.main: Kansas Prosecutor Demands Files On Late-Term Abortion Patients

docs.abstract: Atty Gen Phill Kline of Kansas is demanding complete medical files of scores of women and girls who had late-term abortions, saying he needs information to prosecute criminal cases; emphasizes statutory rape, but court documents suggest other crimes that could include doctors' providing illegal late-term abortions and health professionals' failing to heed state law requiring reporting of suspected child sexual abuse; Kansas law allows late-term abortion only if woman's health is endangered; 30 other states ban or restrict procedure; Kline's effort last year to require state's health workers to report any sexual activity of girls younger than 16 was thwarted when health-care providers sued; advocates on both sides of abortion issue say Kline's new and broad investigation, backed by judge's subpoena, is first of its kind in pursuit of criminal charges; federal Justice Dept has unsuccessfully sought similar records in its defense of ban on what critics call partial-birth abortion; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Attorney General Phill Kline, a Republican, said that he needs the information to prosecute criminal cases.

byline.original: By JODI WILGOREN; Gretchen Ruethling contributed reporting from Chicago for this article

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Wade F. Horn, an assistant secretary of health and human services, writes (letter, Feb. 23):

docs.lead_paragraph: Last fall, as Americans were choosing sides over gay marriage and arguing about campaign references to Vice President Dick Cheney's openly gay daughter, there was one concern quietly uniting people across the ideological spectrum: Bianca Montgomery deserved to get her baby back. Bianca, the heroine of the ABC soap opera ''All My Children,'' is also the first lead character on a major daytime drama to be a lesbian. Controversial at first -- as Bianca revealed her sexuality to her horrified, hyper-heterosexual mother Erica Kane in 2000 -- the character eventually became hugely popular as she braved the sudsy perils of the soaps: she survived a rape that left her pregnant, had her baby stolen in a kidnapping, and navigated months of teeth-gnashing plot twists that kept her daughter just a DNA test away.

headline.main: After Coming Out, a Soap Opera Heroine Moves On

docs.abstract: Article on successful evolution of Bianca Montgomery, character on ABC soap opera all My Children who became first lead character on major daytime drama to be lesbian; Eden Riegel, 24-year-old actress who has played Bianca since 2000, is leaving show today and plans to audition for fall pilots in Los Angeles; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Daytime television's first lesbian major character and the actress who portrays her are preparing to move on from ABC's "All My Children."

docs.lead_paragraph: The military has spent more than $200 million to recruit and train personnel to replace troops discharged in the last decade for being openly gay, a new Congressional study has found. The review by the Government Accountability Office, an investigative arm of Congress, was requested by more than 20 lawmakers who were concerned about the costs of the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy instituted in the Clinton administration, particularly for service members with ''critical occupations'' and ''important foreign language skills.''

headline.main: Rules on Gays Exact a Cost In Recruiting, A Study Finds

docs.abstract: Government Accountability Office study finds that military has spent more than $200 million to recruit and train personnel to replace troops discharged in last decade for being openly gay (M)
docs.snippet: In the last decade, more than 10,000 service members have been discharged for being openly gay, at a cost of $200 million to replace them.
